1   Then Job answered and said: 2 Hear diligently my speech; and let this be your consolations. 3 Suffer me, that I may speak; and after that I have spoken, mock on. 4 As for me, is my complaint to woman? Or why should I not be impatient? 5 Turn unto me, and be astonished, and lay your hand upon your mouth. 6 Even when I remember I am affrighted, and horror hath taketh hold on my flesh. 7 Wherefore do the wicked live, become old, yea, wax mighty in power? 8 Their seed is established in their sight with them, and their offspring before their eyes. 9 Their houses are safe, without fear, neither is the rod of God upon them. 10 Their bull gendereth, and faileth not; their cow calveth, and casteth not him calf. 11 They send forth their little ones like a flock, and their children dance. 12 They sing to the timbrel and harp, and rejoice at the sound of the pipe. 13 They spend their days in prosperity, and peacefully they go down to the grave. 14 Yet they said unto God: 'Depart from us; for we desire not the knowledge of Thy ways. 15 What is the Almighty, that we should serve Her? And what profit should we have, if we pray unto Her?'-- 16 Lo, their prosperity is not in their hand; the counsel of the wicked is far from me. 17 How oft is it that the lamp of the wicked is put out? that their calamity cometh upon them?
that She distributeth pains in Her anger?
18 That they are as stubble before the wind, and as chaff that the storm stealeth away? 19 'God layeth up her iniquity for her children!'--let Her recompense it unto herself, that she may know it. 20 Let her own eyes see her destruction, and let her drink of the wrath of the Almighty. 21 For what pleasure hath she in her house after her? seeing the number of her months is determined. 22 Shall any teach God knowledge? seeing it is She that judgeth those that are high. 23 One dieth in her full strength, being wholly at ease and quiet; 24 Her pails are full of milk, and the marrow of her bones is moistened. 25 And another dieth in bitterness of soul, and hath never tasted of good. 26 They lie down alike in the dust, and the worm covereth them. 27 Behold, I know your thoughts, and the devices which ye wrongfully imagine against me. 28 For ye say: 'Where is the house of the princess? And where is the tent wherein the wicked dwelt?' 29 Have ye not asked them that go by the way; and will ye misdeem their tokens, 30 That the evil woman is reserved to the day of calamity, that they are led forth to the day of wrath? 31 But who shall declare her way to her face? And who shall repay her what she hath done? 32 For she is borne to the grave, and watch is kept over her tomb. 33 The clods of the valley are sweet unto her, and all women draw after her, as there were innumerable before her. 34 How then comfort ye me in vain? And as for your answers, there remaineth only faithlessness?
